articles.headline: At the Paris Air Show, Anticipating a Surge in Sales
articles.snippet: Orders for new and more fuel-efficient jets are anticipated at the show as the global aerospace industry continues to rebound.
articles.abstract: Orders for new and more fuel-efficient jets are anticipated at the show as the global aerospace industry continues to rebound.
articles.lead_paragraph: PARIS — Their corporate chalets may be a touch less spacious and their delegations less numerous, but the titans of the global aerospace industry are returning to Paris this year for what most aviation executives expect will be an affirmation of a steady recovery that is likely to translate into a flurry of orders for newer and more fuel-efficient jets.

articles.headline: 2 Big Banks Exit Reverse Mortgage Business
articles.snippet: Wells Fargo and Bank of America have left the business, as falling home prices have made it more unpredictable.
articles.abstract: Wells Fargo and Bank of America have left the business, as falling home prices have made it more unpredictable.
articles.lead_paragraph: The nation’s two biggest providers of reverse mortgages are no longer offering the loans, as the economics of the business have come under pressure.

articles.headline: 2 Top Lawyers Lost to Obama in Libya War Policy Debate
articles.snippet: President Obama rejected the views of lawyers on his administration’s legal team when he decided he had the authority to continue U.S. participation in Libya without Congressional authorization.
articles.abstract: President Obama rejected the views of lawyers on his administration’s legal team when he decided he had the authority to continue U.S. participation in Libya without Congressional authorization.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama rejected the views of top lawyers at the Pentagon and the Justice Department when he decided that he had the legal authority to continue American military participation in the air war in Libya without Congressional authorization, according to officials familiar with internal administration deliberations.

articles.headline: Deploying New Tools to Stop the Hackers
articles.snippet: Security expects say that new hacking threats from smartphone and Web links require a new generation of tools.
articles.abstract: Security expects say that new hacking threats from smartphone and Web links require a new generation of tools.
articles.lead_paragraph: Trying to secure a computer network is much like trying to secure a building — the challenge is trying to screen out real threats without impeding the normal traffic that needs to go in and out.
articles.byline: By Christopher Drew and Verne G. Kopytoff

articles.headline: U.S. Pressing Its Crackdown Against Leaks
articles.snippet: The case of Stephen J. Kim, an arms expert, is next in line in the Obama administration’s unprecedented campaign after the crumbling of the case again Thomas A. Drake.
articles.abstract: The case of Stephen J. Kim, an arms expert, is next in line in the Obama administration’s unprecedented campaign after the crumbling of the case again Thomas A. Drake.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Stephen J. Kim, an arms expert who immigrated from South Korea as a child, spent a decade briefing top government officials on the dangers posed by North Korea. Then last August he was charged with violating the Espionage Act — not by aiding some foreign adversary, but by revealing classified information to a Fox News reporter.

articles.headline: Frozen Dead Guy Festival for Sale (the Man Himself Stays on Ice)
articles.snippet: The Nederland Area Chamber of Commerce is selling the name and rights to their annual late-winter “Frozen Dead Guy Days,” festival.
articles.abstract: The Nederland Area Chamber of Commerce is selling the name and rights to their annual late-winter “Frozen Dead Guy Days,” festival.
articles.lead_paragraph: NEDERLAND, Colo. — As a business opportunity, Nederland’s frozen dead guy is pretty hot right now. Well, technically, of course, he’s still frozen, packed in dry ice in a shed outside town, as he has been for going on 20 years.

articles.headline: For Want of a Word, Arizona’s Jobless Lose Checks
articles.snippet: Because of ideological opposition and other priorities, Arizona has not made the one-word change necessary to keep the federally financed benefits going.
articles.abstract: Because of ideological opposition and other priorities, Arizona has not made the one-word change necessary to keep the federally financed benefits going.
articles.lead_paragraph: One word, just one little word.

articles.headline: A Watchdog Professor, Now Defending Himself
articles.snippet: David Protess made a name for himself as the Innocence Project he led exonerated a dozen wrongly convicted defendants. Then he locked horns with a prosecutor.
articles.abstract: David Protess made a name for himself as the Innocence Project he led exonerated a dozen wrongly convicted defendants. Then he locked horns with a prosecutor.
articles.lead_paragraph: For the last two years, David Protess, a renowned journalist and professor who spent three decades fighting to prove the innocence of others, has been locked in a battle to do the same for himself. It hasn’t gone as well.
articles.byline: By David Carr and John Schwartz

articles.headline: The King of Really Big Diamonds Heads to China
articles.snippet: Laurence Graff, seller of seriously big and valuable diamonds, sees huge potential in Asia’s rising numbers of wealthy shoppers.
articles.abstract: Laurence Graff, seller of seriously big and valuable diamonds, sees huge potential in Asia’s rising numbers of wealthy shoppers.
articles.lead_paragraph: ON this big night out, Gisele Bündchen, darling of the cameras, is decked out in diamond earrings from Van Cleef & Arpels. The cover girl Shalom Harlow wears rocks from Harry Winston. And Madonna, that proto-Gaga, is bejeweled in Cartier.

articles.headline: Paychecks as Big as Tajikistan
articles.snippet: How executives’ pay stacks up against a company’s earnings or stock market performance is rarely laid out. Now a report bares all the unpleasant details.
articles.abstract: How executives’ pay stacks up against a company’s earnings or stock market performance is rarely laid out. Now a report bares all the unpleasant details.
articles.lead_paragraph: WHEN does big become excessive? If the question involves executive pay, the answer is “often.”

articles.headline: Lessons in Longevity, From I.B.M.
articles.snippet: Evolving beyond past success is a daunting task for all kinds of companies. I.B.M.’s experience offers pointers for giants like Microsoft, Google and Apple.
articles.abstract: Evolving beyond past success is a daunting task for all kinds of companies. I.B.M.’s experience offers pointers for giants like Microsoft, Google and Apple.
articles.lead_paragraph: AS it turned 100 last week, I.B.M. was looking remarkably spry. Consumer technologies get all the attention these days, but the company has quietly thrived by selling to corporations and governments. Profits are strong, its portfolio of products and services looks robust, and its shares are near a record high. I.B.M.’s stock-market value passed Google’s earlier this year. Not bad for a corporate centenarian.

articles.headline: Friendship of Justice and Magnate Puts Focus on Ethics
articles.snippet: A Georgia project has thrown a spotlight on an unusual, and ethically sensitive, friendship between Justice Clarence Thomas and a wealthy supporter.
articles.abstract: A Georgia project has thrown a spotlight on an unusual, and ethically sensitive, friendship between Justice Clarence Thomas and a wealthy supporter.
articles.lead_paragraph: PIN POINT, Ga. — Clarence Thomas was here promoting his memoir a few years ago when he bumped into Algernon Varn, whose grandfather once ran a seafood cannery that employed Justice Thomas’s mother as a crab picker.

articles.headline: Qaeda Woes Fuel Talk of Speeding Afghan Pullback
articles.snippet: High-ranking officials say Al Qaeda’s original network in the region is crippled, providing a rationale for an accelerated troop reduction.
articles.abstract: High-ranking officials say Al Qaeda’s original network in the region is crippled, providing a rationale for an accelerated troop reduction.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — As the Obama administration nears a crucial decision on how rapidly to withdraw combat forces from Afghanistan, high-ranking officials say that Al Qaeda’s original network in the region has been crippled, providing a rationale for an accelerated reduction of troops.
articles.byline: By Mark Landler and Helene Cooper

articles.headline: Obama’s Views on Gay Marriage ‘Evolving’
articles.snippet: A review of President Obama’s record suggests that he may have been for same-sex marriage before he was against it.
articles.abstract: A review of President Obama’s record suggests that he may have been for same-sex marriage before he was against it.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Driving across the flatlands of Illinois with Barack Obama during the Senate race of 2004, Kevin Thompson sometimes found himself tutoring the candidate on gay rights.

articles.headline: Backlog of Cases Gives a Reprieve on Foreclosures
articles.snippet: With lenders wary of repossessed houses and a foreclosure system that is bogged down, homeowners in distress are getting breathing room.
articles.abstract: With lenders wary of repossessed houses and a foreclosure system that is bogged down, homeowners in distress are getting breathing room.
articles.lead_paragraph: Millions of homeowners in distress are getting some unexpected breathing room — lots of it in some places.

articles.headline: Deal on Lifeline to Avert Greek Bankruptcy Is Postponed
articles.snippet: European finance ministers failed to agree on 12 billion euros in financial aid for the Athens government.
articles.abstract: European finance ministers failed to agree on 12 billion euros in financial aid for the Athens government.
articles.lead_paragraph: LUXEMBOURG — Europe’s finance ministers unexpectedly put off approval early Monday of the next installment of aid to debt-laden Greece, delaying the decision until July and demanding that the Greek Parliament first approve spending cuts and financial reforms that include a large-scale privatization program.
articles.byline: By Stephen Castle and Niki Kitsantonis

articles.headline: At New Network, Olbermann Sets Sights on MSNBC
articles.snippet: MSNBC will have some competition on the left as Keith Olbermann and a raft of contributors join Current TV.
articles.abstract: MSNBC will have some competition on the left as Keith Olbermann and a raft of contributors join Current TV.
articles.lead_paragraph: Starting on Monday, there will be new competition for progressive attention spans on television.

articles.headline: For 2012 Hopeful, Envoy Job in China Was a Useful Detour
articles.snippet: A decision by Jon M. Huntsman Jr., President Obama’s former envoy to China, to run for president has prompted suspicion among Mr. Obama’s advisers.
articles.abstract: A decision by Jon M. Huntsman Jr., President Obama’s former envoy to China, to run for president has prompted suspicion among Mr. Obama’s advisers.
articles.lead_paragraph: As guests including Barbra Streisand and Yo Yo Ma mingled in three resplendent rooms in the White House in January to honor President Hu Jintao of China, David Axelrod, President Obama’s senior strategist, needed to take care of some political housekeeping.

articles.headline: Investors Provide Millions to Risky Start-Ups
articles.snippet: Some analysts are concerned that venture capitalists are blindly throwing money at start-ups that have not yet proved they can build something useful.
articles.abstract: Some analysts are concerned that venture capitalists are blindly throwing money at start-ups that have not yet proved they can build something useful.
articles.lead_paragraph: PALO ALTO, Calif. — What if you threw a $41 million party and nobody came? A start-up company called Color knows how that feels.

articles.headline: Ugly Details in Selling Newspapers
articles.snippet: James O’Shea reported out the deals that tipped over the owners of The Los Angeles Times and The Chicago Tribune.
articles.abstract: James O’Shea reported out the deals that tipped over the owners of The Los Angeles Times and The Chicago Tribune.
articles.lead_paragraph: Any look behind the curtain of Wall Street is not going to be pretty. But there is not pretty and then there is plain ugly.

articles.headline: Within the Industry, an Urge to Cash Out
articles.snippet: Employees and investors at dozens of hot start-ups have sold hundreds of millions of dollars’ worth of shares.
articles.abstract: Employees and investors at dozens of hot start-ups have sold hundreds of millions of dollars’ worth of shares.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — While Silicon Valley and Wall Street debate whether a new technology bubble is in the making, some early Facebook employees are not taking any chances. They’re leaving the company to cash out on millions of dollars in stock options while Facebook’s valuation continues to soar.

articles.headline: Small Group Rode LinkedIn to Big Payday
articles.snippet: LinkedIn’s debut illustrates how insiders can get rich in the social networking bonanza.
articles.abstract: LinkedIn’s debut illustrates how insiders can get rich in the social networking bonanza.
articles.lead_paragraph: For Reid Hoffman, the chairman of LinkedIn, it took less than 30 minutes to earn himself an extra $200 million.

articles.headline: Companies Push for Tax Break on Foreign Cash
articles.snippet: Some large corporations are pushing for a tax holiday to bring back offshore profits, but the economic benefits were limited the last time such a break was given.
articles.abstract: Some large corporations are pushing for a tax holiday to bring back offshore profits, but the economic benefits were limited the last time such a break was given.
articles.lead_paragraph: Some of the nation’s largest corporations have amassed vast profits outside the country and are pressing Congress and the Obama administration for a tax break to bring the money home.

articles.headline: Few Taliban Leaders Take Afghan Offer to Switch Sides
articles.snippet: There are as many as 40,000 Taliban fighters in Afghanistan, but only 1,700 of them have agreed to switch sides.
articles.abstract: There are as many as 40,000 Taliban fighters in Afghanistan, but only 1,700 of them have agreed to switch sides.
articles.lead_paragraph: KANDAHAR, Afghanistan — Toor Jan, who used to kill Americans and Canadians here, does not want much from the Afghan government. A home. A job. And, yes, eight security guards.

articles.headline: War Evolves With Drones, Some Tiny as Bugs
articles.snippet: From blimps to bugs, an explosion in aerial drones is transforming the way America fights and thinks about its wars.
articles.abstract: From blimps to bugs, an explosion in aerial drones is transforming the way America fights and thinks about its wars.
articles.lead_paragraph: WRIGHT-PATTERSON AIR FORCE BASE, Ohio — Two miles from the cow pasture where the Wright Brothers learned to fly the first airplanes, military researchers are at work on another revolution in the air: shrinking unmanned drones, the kind that fire missiles into Pakistan and spy on insurgents in Afghanistan, to the size of insects and birds.
articles.byline: By Elisabeth Bumiller and Thom Shanker

articles.headline: Assad Offers Path to Change in Syria, but Few Specifics
articles.snippet: President Bashar al-Assad has offered a dialogue, but the question remains: If the government is sincere, whom would it talk to?
articles.abstract: President Bashar al-Assad has offered a dialogue, but the question remains: If the government is sincere, whom would it talk to?
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — In his first address in two months, President Bashar al-Assad of Syria on Monday offered a national dialogue that he said could usher in change to a country where his party and family have monopolized authority for four decades.

articles.headline: Justices Rule for Wal-Mart in Class-Action Bias Case
articles.snippet: The Supreme Court ruled for Wal-Mart in blocking a lawsuit that had sought to consolidate claims of up to 1.5 million women who worked there.
articles.abstract: The Supreme Court ruled for Wal-Mart in blocking a lawsuit that had sought to consolidate claims of up to 1.5 million women who worked there.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court on Monday threw out an enormous employment discrimination class-action suit against Wal-Mart that had sought billions of dollars on behalf of as many as 1.5 million female workers.
